ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A basic foundation of Chinese art history, introduction to famous painters, collectors, and other artists. Intriguing lectures about numerous different Chinese philosophies as well as tropes in Chinese art. Some topics include Peach Blossom Spring, Immortal Mountains, Antiquarianism in Bronze Vessels, and Funerary Art. The theme of Time in Chinese Art was very effectively used to provide a diverse learning experience.
It offers me a unique perspective to view the Chinese artworks.
Great overview of major topics/themes in Chinese art, with interesting framing of major ideas through the concept of "time." Provided good introduction to the work of contemporary artists.
We developed a strong understanding of different topics of Chinese art and their connections to temporality. We also got to further develop our visual analysis skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Each week centered around a different facet of time in Chinese art, so a very diverse and interesting array of topics were introduced. Professor Ngan also provided many fascinating readings and showed numerous artworks, including pieces from the YUAG. 

Weaknesses: This was definitely due to the nature of online lectures, but class participation in lecture discussions was often limited. Also, as an undergrad I felt self-conscious about speaking especially surrounded by upperclassmen and graduate students. But this was rectified in the weekly discussion sections.
We learned a lot from the corse, but it can be better if we have more time for discussion in every class.

The theme of this class was unique and provided a good framework for discussions as well as essay topics. Professor Ngan's lectures were organized and engaging, each provided a unique perspective on the concept of time. The topics discussed in the course were broad, yet the professor was able to bring out key concepts that appeared throughout the course.
I think that the strength lies in the teaching and the care of the professor and the TF. I think a way this course could be improved is to have more suggested additional readings.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lectures are well-designed. It can be improved if we have opportunity to look at artworks in art galleries and museums, which would be possible if it's not an online course.
Course was engaging despite remote format - good combination of lecture and discussion-based learning.
I think the professor really put in effort to make sure each student had the opportunity to do well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, even if you are not big on art or art history, this class offers valuable insight into Chinese history and the evolution of Chinese art. You are given the opportunity to explore a variety of mediums from ancient paintings to cinema to contemporary art. You also learn about systems that shaped Chinese art, including but not limited to Daoism, Confucianism, dynastic time, and Communism. If you are Chinese, I think this class is very valuable as it will teach you a lot about your cultural heritage, from the first August Emperor all the way to modern-day.
Yes, if you want to learn about how to analyze artworks, especially Chinese art.
Yes, to both majors and nonmajors. The course topic is interesting and unique, presented a new framework by which to think about Chinese art.

I would strongly recommend this course. I took the Intro Asian Art class and this class takes the basic knowledge of Chinese art to another level. The theme of temporality is super fascinating and is so relevant to the study of art history.
Very good class for an unconventional introduction to Chinese art. Would recommend.

comments: Weekly discussion section
On Monday there is a virtual discussion section.
